Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Multiscale Strategy for Nano- and Bio- Structures: Deformation, Defects, and Electromechanics

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to investigate the use of fundamental structural symmetries for multiscale calculations of structural defects in systems of importance to nanotechnology and life sciences. The focus nanostructures are carbon nanotubes and graphene, and the focus biological structures are DNA molecules and lipid membranes. Structural defects can have huge impacts: for example, carbon nanotube networks with junctions can behave as soft and ultra-low-weight electromechanical materials; voids in graphene can cause failure, or even enable new properties such as piezoelectricity in non-piezoelectric perfect graphene; mechanical kinks in DNA can affect electron transport and consequently biological function; and the exit and entry of biomolecules to the cell is essentially through the formation of defects in lipid membranes. The research strategy will use a unifying description of the underlying structural symmetries in these various systems to enable multiscale calculations of defect properties, in particular the role of defects in deformation and electron transport.

The outcomes of the project will include new methods for complex bio- and nano-structures, and the scientific insights of the focus studies can provide strategies for designing and optimizing new materials with complex structure. This project plans a number of educational activities that are closely integrated with the research. This includes a new National Engineer Week exhibit based on symmetry and collective behavior; involving undergraduates in the proposed research; training a PhD student; the development of interdisciplinary graduate courses on "Multiscale Modeling"; and the organization of conference sessions on topics related to the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award was to investigate the use of fundamental structural symmetries for multiscale calculations of structural defects in systems of importance to nanotechnology and life sciences. The research strategy used a unifying description of the underlying structural symmetries in these various systems to enable multiscale calculations. A number of findings have spawned new research projects that are ongoing by the PI as well as other groups.

 

Specific contributions include:

 

1. The project has developed a generalization of the phonon analysis for the setting of complex nanostructures with helical symmetries. We have then applied this to classify the various types of phonon modes, and examined the use of phonons to study thermal transport as a function of broad geometric parameters (as opposed to specific forms of interatomic force fields) and the use of phonons to predict instabilities. An interesting finding as a consequence of this work was that certain wave speed in nanotubes are not material properties but rather structural properties; that is, they depend sensitively on the boundary conditions.

 

2. The project has developed a multiscale method for the transport of electrons in nanostructures, and particularly their scattering at defects. We have developed a new formulation of the radiation boundary condition that is appropriate for periodic media and the Schrodinger equation, and applied this to examine Klein scattering in graphene.

 

3. The project has developed new techniques to analyze the behavior of electromechanically coupled materials at the nanoscale. These approaches have provided new metamaterial designs for temperature-stable electromechanical coupling and enhanced electromechanical coupling in polymeric systems. The ideas developed here were also used to study experimental realizations of optically-responsive polymers that demonstrate photomotility.

 

4. The project has developed multiscale methods to model the behavior of lipid membranes. Various aspects of lipid membranes have been examined, ranging from continuum evolution models to mesoscale defect models to molecular multiscale calculations of endocytosis. As a part of this effort, a significant theoretical advance to generalize symmetry groups to the notion of “approximate” symmetry groups was introduced.

 

5. The propagation of electromagnetic waves in two dimensional systems such as graphene with curvature (non flat two dimensional geometry) has been formulated and is being applied to specific examples to obtain insights.

 

6. The nonequilibrium behavior of carbon nanotubes was studied using time dependent symmetry groups, in particular their rate dependent response and the failure modes. As an extension to this, similar nonequilibrium solution methods for the Boltzmann equation are being applied and compared to classical molecular dynamics as a critical test of the Boltzmann equation to provide a physical description of non equilibrium phenomena.

 

7. As part of the REU supplement program, a new nonlocal method to model topological defects in liquid crystals was formulated and applied to study the behavior of a number of physical situation of current interest. Key contributions of this work include (1) a characterization of the stability and decomposition of various disclinations, and the competition between bend and splay energies in determining the relative stability of integer and half-integer disclinations, and (2) the coalescence of

disclination pair of equal and opposite strength. In (2), we find the disclinations do not move at the same velocities towards each other, suggesting that the asymmetry of the director field plays a dominant role despite the equal-and-opposite topological strengths of the disclinations.

 

In terms of training students, this grant has partially supported the efforts of 4 PhD students. In addition, 5 REU students have been supported by supplements affiliated to this grant. Of these REU students, 2 are from under-represented groups and 1 is female. One of these under-represented students has gone to graduate (the PhD program in engineering at Caltech). In addition, a number of outreach activities including K-12 outreach through participation in National Engineer Week have been conducted.
